author: etan_status
content: pureth allows verification of the RPC responses (the helios style lightclient would live inside the wallet and verify). meaning you are no longer bound to a small number of trusted servers, but can use any public RPC that's out there. same goes for the things that currently need indexers. For example, raw eth_getLogs currently is quite unreliable / incomplete / slow to use, so even for basic use cases such as wallet history a trusted indexer is needed today. dropping the need to use trusted servers for basic use cases means backups are available

author: etan_status
content: you need a trusted one, today's wallets don't verify anything that the RPC tells them

author: etan_status
content:
No, with Helios you can connect to _any_ public RPC, not just trusted ones. That's the point of it!
And if AWS down, anyone can simply spin one up on Google Cloud, and then just point to that one (it cannot trick you into fake data)

However, Helios today is artificially limited by API inefficiencies (e.g., require download of multiple receipts to obtain gas_used etc), and incomplete data (e.g., logs are not feasible to verify, and are also incomplete regarding ETH transfers and staking rewards)

author: etan_status
content: and your own indexer? because even with the own node, it's not feasible to obtain a history of all ETH transfers pertaining to your wallet. you have to trace every single transaction for side effects using debug API to find out if someone sent you ETH with a SELFDESTRUCT/SENDALL in some tx (that's what the exchanges have to do to detect user deposits from certain smart contract wallets)
